annotation.text: In addition, PECAM-1, which is expressed in endothelial cells, monocytes, neutrophils and specific T lymphocyte subsets, is directly involved in diapedesis via homophilic interactions between migrating leukocytes, particularly monocytes/neutrophils and endothelial intercellular junctions (Muller et al. 1993).

aradoxically, however, gene deficiency for PECAM-1 was recently found to increase the number of activated leukocytes crossing the BBB, suggesting that PECAM-1 might play a more complex role in leukocyte extravasation than previously recognized (Graesser et al. 2002).

In addition, PECAM-1, which is expressed in endothelial cells, monocytes, neutrophils and specific T lymphocyte subsets, is directly involved in diapedesis via homophilic interactions between migrating leukocytes, particularly monocytes/neutrophils and endothelial intercellular junctions

Using brain endothelial cell lines, we previously provided evidence that ICAM-1 antibody cross-linking led to an increase in intracellular Ca2+ concentration, protein kinase C activation, phosphorylation of cortactin and other actin-binding proteins by the Src tyrosine kinase, activation of RhoA GTPase, and subsequent rearrangements of the actin cytoskeleton (Durieu-Trautmann et al. 1994; Greenwood et al. 2002; Carman and Springer 2004; Shaw et al. 2004; Yang et al. 2005; Millan et al. 2006).

annotation.infon: elevation of cytosolic calcium ion concentration|GO:0007204
annotation.text: Using brain endothelial cell lines, we previously provided evidence that ICAM-1 antibody cross-linking led to an increase in intracellular Ca2+ concentration, protein kinase C activation, phosphorylation of cortactin and other actin-binding proteins by the Src tyrosine kinase, activation of RhoA GTPase, and subsequent rearrangements of the actin cytoskeleton (Durieu-Trautmann et al. 1994; Greenwood et al. 2002; Carman and Springer 2004; Shaw et al. 2004; Yang et al. 2005; Millan et al. 2006).

Using brain endothelial cell lines, we previously provided evidence that ICAM-1 antibody cross-linking led to an increase in intracellular Ca2+ concentration, protein kinase C activation, phosphorylation of cortactin and other actin-binding proteins by the Src tyrosine kinase, activation of RhoA GTPase, and subsequent rearrangements of the actin cytoskeleton (Durieu-Trautmann et al. 1994; Greenwood et al. 2002; Carman and Springer 2004; Shaw et al. 2004; Yang et al. 2005; Millan et al. 2006).

Using brain endothelial cell lines, we previously provided evidence that ICAM-1 antibody cross-linking led to an increase in intracellular Ca2+ concentration, protein kinase C activation, phosphorylation of cortactin and other actin-binding proteins by the Src tyrosine kinase, activation of RhoA GTPase, and subsequent rearrangements of the actin cytoskeleton (Durieu-Trautmann et al. 1994; Greenwood et al. 2002; Carman and Springer 2004; Shaw et al. 2004; Yang et al. 2005; Millan et al. 2006).

Besides, PECAM-1 has been abundantly documented as a signaling receptor which can transduce either inhibitory or stimulatory signals with cell-specificity, such as inhibition of the antigen receptor signaling in T lymphocytes or stimulation of the intracellular calcium level in endothelial cells (Newman et al. 2001; Newman and Newman 2003).

annotation.infon: positive regulation of Rho GTPase activity|GO:0032321
annotation.text: Following ICAM-1 cross-linking or control treatment, cell extracts containing equal amounts of RhoA protein (as confirmed by western blotting: not shown) were incubated with the the Rhotekin-GST fusion protein: a large amount of retained (i.e. activated) RhoA was detected following ICAM-1 cross-linking (Fig. 1f, lane b), compared to basal conditions (Fig. 1f, lane a), confirming our previous finding that ICAM-1 cross-linking induces a strong activation of RhoA in RBE4 cells.

Following ICAM-1 cross-linking or control treatment, cell extracts containing equal amounts of RhoA protein (as confirmed by western blotting: not shown) were incubated with the the Rhotekin-GST fusion protein: a large amount of retained (i.e. activated) RhoA was detected following ICAM-1 cross-linking (Fig. 1f, lane b), compared to basal conditions (Fig. 1f, lane a), confirming our previous finding that ICAM-1 cross-linking induces a strong activation of RhoA in RBE4 cells.

annotation.infon: negative regulation of Rho GTPase activity|GO:0034259
annotation.text: PECAM-1 cross-linking per se did not activate RhoA (Fig. 1f, lane c), but completely inhibited ICAM-1-induced RhoA activation (Fig. 1f, lane d). As a control, the irrelevant isotype-matched anti-MHC-II antibody had no effect on ICAM-1 response (Fig. 1f, lane e). These results provide further evidence that PECAM-1 cross-linking affects the ICAM-1-induced cortical actin polymerization by interfering with RhoA activation.

Together with actin polymerization, we previously documented that ICAM-1 cross-linking strongly stimulated the tyrosine kinase Src activity and tyrosine phosphorylation of several actin-binding proteins, including cortactin. This response was maintained over extended periods of time (for at least 60 min)

As shown in Fig. 2, while ICAM-1 cross-linking strongly enhanced cortactin tyrosine phosphorylation in RBE4 cells (Fig. 2a, lanes b and c), PECAM-1 cross-linking, which had no effect alone (Fig. 2a, lane d), markedly reduced ICAM-1-induced cortactin phosphorylation

As shown in Fig. 2, while ICAM-1 cross-linking strongly enhanced cortactin tyrosine phosphorylation in RBE4 cells (Fig. 2a, lanes b and c), PECAM-1 cross-linking, which had no effect alone (Fig. 2a, lane d), markedly reduced ICAM-1-induced cortactin phosphorylation
Partial inhibition of ICAM-1-induced cortactin phosphorylation was already observed after only 5 min of PECAM-1 cross-linking (not shown).
Partial inhibition of ICAM-1-induced cortactin phosphorylation was already observed after only 5 min of PECAM-1 cross-linking (not shown).

PECAM-1 cross-linking reverses ICAM-1-induced cortactin phosphorylation. Sequential cross-linking of ICAM-1 and/or PECAM-1 was performed on IFN-gamma-treated RBE4 cells or HBMECs as described in Material and methods.

PECAM-1 cross-linking reverses ICAM-1-induced cortactin phosphorylation. Sequential cross-linking of ICAM-1 and/or PECAM-1 was performed on IFN-gamma-treated RBE4 cells or HBMECs as described in Material and methods.
Panel (c) PECAM-1 cross-linking prevents ICAM-1-induced cortactin phosphorylation in RBE4 cells.
Panel (c) PECAM-1 cross-linking prevents ICAM-1-induced cortactin phosphorylation in RBE4 cells.

Figure 2c reveals that inhibition of ICAM-1-induced cortactin phosphorylation was even more drastic in this case (Fig. 2c, lanes P + I) than when PECAM-1 cross-linking followed ICAM-1 cross-linking as above (Fig. 2c, lanes I + P).

Figure 2c reveals that inhibition of ICAM-1-induced cortactin phosphorylation was even more drastic in this case (Fig. 2c, lanes P + I) than when PECAM-1 cross-linking followed ICAM-1 cross-linking as above (Fig. 2c, lanes I + P).

Altogether, these findings support the conclusion that PECAM-1 engagement on the surface of brain (and non-brain) endothelial cells drastically inhibits multiple ICAM-1 signaling pathways, including cortactin phosphorylation and actin rearrangements.

annotation.infon: negative regulation of actin filament polymerization|GO:0030837
annotation.text: Altogether, these findings support the conclusion that PECAM-1 engagement on the surface of brain (and non-brain) endothelial cells drastically inhibits multiple ICAM-1 signaling pathways, including cortactin phosphorylation and actin rearrangements.
The tyrosine phosphatase SHP-2, is known to bind to activated PECAM-1.

In conclusion, the main findings of the current study are summarized in Fig. 5: they demonstrate that SHP-2 is positively involved in ICAM-1 signaling, upstream of the tyrosine phosphorylation of cortactin by Src and of RhoA-mediated actin cytoskeleton rearrangements.

In conclusion, the main findings of the current study are summarized in Fig. 5: they demonstrate that SHP-2 is positively involved in ICAM-1 signaling, upstream of the tyrosine phosphorylation of cortactin by Src and of RhoA-mediated actin cytoskeleton rearrangements.
More importantly, our results show that PECAM-1 engagement, which induces a strong interaction with SHP-2,
More importantly, our results show that PECAM-1 engagement, which induces a strong interaction with SHP-2,
drastically inhibits these two distinct ICAM-1 activated pathways.
